Skip navigation. Press enter to return to the slide.

resource_data.description: You will find useful additional documents here

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript: Welcome to the DEAL Basics eLearning course!

Voice-over:

DEAL is a Customer Relationship Management System

The intuitive interface of our Customer Relationship Management System, new functionalities, and standardized cross-business processes provide us with an improved overview of our customers and enable us to address their needs more effectively.

We start at the airport. Eva is a Director, and she is on the way to meet Mr. Mayer, an important automotive customer of BVD AG.

On short notice, he has asked for a meeting about Cyber Security to learn about offerings in this area.
While waiting for boarding the airplane, Eva views recent client activities in DEAL.

Eva sees that Mr. Mayer participated in the Cyber Security Summit two weeks ago and that he talked with Mark, the Business Developer for this account.

She decides to ask Mark via Chatter for his viewpoint on this matter.

Eva thanks Mark and boards the plane.

She and Mr. Mayer had a successful meeting, in which they discussed Cyber Security at BVD AG. His new Data Security Lead Martina Schmitt also participated in the meeting. Mr. Mayer was very impressed by the breadth and depth of our Cyber Security offering. On her way back to the airport, Eva plans the next steps.

Eva is pleased with the meeting and wants to hand over this topic to Mark.

She scans the business card of Mrs. Schmitt with her smartphone, adds a new task in DEAL for Mark to set up a follow-up meeting, creates a new Lead and saves her notes about the conversation in DEAL.

The second client meeting was also successful. They have already received a Request for Proposal by the BVD AG to support the implementation of the new Cyber Security strategy. In the meantime, the Lead has already been converted into a qualified Opportunity.

Recently, published a study about Predictive Analytics in the automotive industry. Senior Manager Gregor wants to share this study with his client Lynda, who works for a large Bavarian automotive group. As they have a good client relationship and he has mentioned during their last meeting that he would like to share interesting information with her, he sends the study directly to Lynda. Gregor believes that this will allow him to prove himself once again in his role as Lynda's consultant.

However, Lynda reacts differently than expected...

Lisa is a Senior Manager and just received a Request for Proposal (RfP) to develop a proposal in the field of Compliance.

She creates a new Opportunity in DEAL.

Furthermore, she searches for similar Opportunities in DEAL that used the same product. In one Opportunity, she notices a link to a KX reference. There she finds valuable information, which helps her in developing the proposal.
Before we introduce you to the system basics, we will give you an overview of all processes underlying DEAL.

The DEAL core processes cover the entire customer lifecycle from Lead to Loyalty. We start with the Lead.

Once a Lead has been identified, it is enriched with further information before it is converted into an Account, a Contact and an Opportunity.

An Opportunity is first identified, contacted, then qualified before we submit a proposal and hopefully win the Opportunity.

Once the Engagement has been set up, it is delivered and - potentially - enhanced with additional smaller assignments or changes, before it is ultimately closed.

What happens after an Engagement has been closed? We put all our efforts into developing sustainable long-term client relationships - for example by asking for client feedback or managing our alumni.

The process blocks below are supporting processes, which run in the background. They include additional processes in the fields of Marketing, Independence & Risk, Data Management, and Cross Processes.
In the System Basics chapter, you will learn about DEALs structure and core elements as well as the navigation through DEAL.
The first chapter introduces you to the objectives of and benefits through DEAL.
Lets look at how a change in mindset and behavior can enable us to tap the full potential of DEAL.
In this chapter, you will learn more about the most important processes in DEAL: Lead, Opportunity, and Engagement.
Before we continue with the Engagement, you will get to know the approval processes that are required when creating or converting an Opportunity.

Based on an example, you will receive an overview of the most important approval processes in DEAL. We will also show you which steps are completed automatically by the system, and which ones require manual input.

Lets have a look at client BVD AG with our Lead Client Service Partner Jürgen and the clients Chief Digital Officer, Thomas Albrecht. In general, the Opportunity requires three approval processes before it can be converted into an Engagement. These three business approval processes are all directly integrated in the system. This way, the entire approval workflow is documented in DEAL, and we avoid having to obtain approvals via multiple channels, for example phone or email. Furthermore, this enables Jürgen and his assistant to check which colleague still has an approval outstanding.

After a few preliminary conversations, Jürgen, who acts as the Opportunity Partner, has manually set the Opportunity in DEAL to the stage Contacted.

Through Thomas, receives an RfP from BVD AG. The RfP asks for a proposal in the field of Cloud Solutions. Before Jürgen can submit a proposal, Decision to Bid, the first of three approval processes, must be completed by several approvers in the business.

To start Decision to Bid, Jürgen has to create the Risk Assessment in DEAL. Afterwards, he or his assistant - the Opportunity Admin - can manually start the process by clicking on Start Workflow.

Right after the approval by the Opportunity Partner, who is the first approver in this process, an Opportunity Time Code is automatically created. Thus, it is no longer necessary to backdate Opportunities

After the Decision to Bid process has been completed, the system automatically changes the stage of the Opportunity to Qualified and initiates the Conflict Check. This new functionality within DEAL saves time, so Jürgen and his assistant can focus on more important things. While the Conflict Check is in progress, Jürgen can already start working on the proposal.
In this chapter, you will learn how to create an Account, a Contact, and a Target Group.
Congratulations, you did it! We wish you every success for your Customer Relationship Management with DEAL.
Every employee is responsible for protecting our client data. In this chapter, we will show you what you need to know when it comes to client data in DEAL.

Based on a newly created Contact, we will show you why we can target some Contacts for Marketing activities and others not.

Senior Manager Sina has a personal client contact from her current project, who is not yet existent in DEAL. She thus creates a new Contact in DEAL. Sina can trigger that an email is sent to the Contact asking him to give his Double Opt-In.

With this email, the Contact can confirm that is allowed to process his data and share Marketing material with him.

If he does not respond, he will receive a second reminder. If he still does not confirm that we can contact him, the Contact will be tagged with an advertising/Marketing block. The Marketing block can only be dissolved by BD Central.

In contrast, once he confirms, the contact is activated to be approached for Marketing activities. In some cases, Sina may not want that her Contacts are contacted regarding the Double Opt-In immediately after they have been created in DEAL. In these cases, she can set the Double Opt-In block to prevent it.
Good luck with the final test!
